intro: Syngonanthus rufipes, commonly known as the red-legged spurge, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, which is known for its diverse and often toxic species. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often found in open woodlands and prairies. Its distinctive red stems and yellowish-green leaves make it easily identifiable. Syngonanthus rufipes produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are clustered in a structure called a cyathium, typical of the Euphorbiaceae family.
